subtitle: New Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery.
With parapsychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove and today I am going to talk about phantasms, tulpas and egregores.
Let me state, right at the outset, that my interest in these
subjects is primarily scientific,
in the sense that I think these concepts have
incredible implications for the social and behavioral sciences.
Now the concepts themselves seem to come out of esoteric culture.
They seem to be related to the arts of magic.
But, surely, the arts of magic have enormous
implications for science in general, and have been studiously ignored
by science in general. But I think that’s changing now as I have mentioned several times before - since
the August 2018 article in the American Psychologist - it seems to me
behavioral scientists now have an obligation to take the data of
parapsychology seriously. We can begin with the classic text Phantasms of the Living
authored by Edmund Gurney, Frederic Myers
and, I think, Podmore was the 3rd author.
Phantasms of the Living was a study published toward the end of the 19th
Century which was based on the – how can I put it? –
case studies of individuals who reported apparitions.
These apparitions, it turned out, were based on living people. Apparitions of living people – not apparitions
of the deceased, as one might well imagine. There were plenty of apparitions of the deceased as well,
and those are very important for our study of the possibility of human survival. But that whole
study became, in effect, contaminated by the possibility that apparitions can be produced by the living.
They might be apparitions of living people.
But if a living person can produce an apparition of themselves,
why can’t they produce an apparition that resembles something that is not themselves?
What is an apparition in any case? [Screen note: Such “phantasms” have on occasion been witnessed, simultaneously, by multiple persons.]
The picture gets even more complicated [Screen note: Such “phantasms” have on occasion been witnessed, simultaneously, by multiple persons.]
by the study that was done in the 1970s
at the Toronto Society for Psychical Research. The classic study of Philip the Ghost,
and I’ve talked about that in a previous InPresence monologue, as I recall – I can link to it right now.
But there’s a lot of data about this. When people get together
in a Victorian style séance,
sit around a table and sing songs and enter into a
state of group rapport where they have a common story that they share. In this case, a
fictitious story about a ghost named Philip. What they began producing were
paranormal table raps. One rap for “Yes,” two raps for “No” – or vice versa,
I’m not even sure which. But the important point here is that acoustical studies were done on these raps.
They’re not the kind of raps that you could produce by knocking on a wooden table.
They had a different acoustical signature. They were indeed
paranormal raps and they were responding to questions being posed by the sitters at the séance.
The responses, interestingly enough, were produced
in accordance with the fictitious story about a
medieval ghost named Philip who died tragically, sort of a Gothic tale, romantic circumstances.
But it was a tale. It was a fiction, and yet it produced paranormal effects.
This is becoming quite interesting because it also is
consistent with the notion of the “tulpa.” Now, I first heard about tulpas long ago because
there’s a classic book written by
Alexandra David-Neel, who was a woman, as I recall, early in the 20th Century – around the 1920s or so. At
a time when Tibet was pretty much closed to foreigners, she managed to travel to Tibet.
She became acquainted with Tibetan monks.
You can see her in her Tibetan garb. She reports the creation of a tulpa.
This is something understood in Tibetan Mahayana Buddhism
as an emanation of the mind itself. She began
concentrating on the idea that there was this person,
and the person began to take on a form. She could see the person. Other people could see the person.
Well, she knew it was a creation of her own concentration.
However, it began to take on a life of its own.
It got to become an annoyance. It was insulting people. It was harassing people. A tulpa,
a fictitious figure, that had taken on the cloak of materiality.
Eventually the other Tibetans in her group had to
banish it, or exorcise it, which they understood how to do in their tradition.
Today, we now know there are people who consider themselves tulpamancers.
One of our Thinking Allowed viewers describes himself as a Tulpa Master. If you look on
Wikipedia you can see that amongst computer gamers, people who enter into fantasy worlds where
psychic powers are real, there is a sub-culture of tulpamancers.
People who create these fictitious characters and they take on a life of their own. They could be animals.
They could be My Little Pony, I believe, is one of them.
So, Annie Besant, one of the founders of the Theosophical
movement, or the early pioneers – it was founded by others, Madame Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott –
but Annie Besant came shortly thereafter, and she acknowledged that these tulpas can take on
different forms. They can be the form of the person creating them. They can be a form
of something that that person imagines but they can even go a little deeper. They can take on a thought form.
Something not a personality, not a person, not an entity, but an idea.
That brings us to the next level – egregores. What is an egregore?
Here, I think, we get back to the behavioral sciences, to sociology.
Emile Durkheim, the great French researcher who is one of the founders of the whole field of sociology,
had this notion that the deities of any particular culture, Jesus Christ, for example, is a projection
of the group mind of that culture.
Now of course this came in the 19th Century, a period of the height of materialistic thinking.
I think people didn’t take Durkheim literally. They thought of the group mind as a
as a kind of symbolic thing.
But if we look at the research now on phantasms,
and Philip the Ghost who is in effect a tulpa, if we begin to take
parapsychology seriously, we have to look at the group mind in a new way.
The egregore is related, I think, to the word aggregation.
The aggregation: when a collective of people hold a certain thought form
together in their mind. Now that thought form could be a deity. It could be Jesus Christ. It could be
a satanic figure, a demonic figure. It could be Allah. It could be Yahweh.
It could be Prometheus, as my friend Jason, I believe, pictures it.
These are, you might say, products of the individual minds in the group
but then they begin to take on a life of their own, just like Alexandra
David-Neel’s tulpa. Sometimes they get out of control.
Perhaps they even need to be banished. We’ve done programs on the idea of rebellion against God.
There can be a point at which our own thoughts
take on a life of their own and begin to dominate us. We
recently released an interview on conspiracy theories, and I hear from so many viewers who believe that these
conspiracies are real. But imagine if the
source of the conspiracy are your own thoughts.
Consider that. It may be a thought that we have collectively produced
that takes on a life of its own, exists in what my friend Marty Rosenblatt calls the Universe
of Collective Consciousness.
This just opens up a whole new vista for exploration. I’m sure many behavioral scientists, if you’re listening to my
monologue, you’re throwing up your hands and saying, “How are we supposed to deal with this?
It’s too amorphous. It’s too nebulous. It needs to be operationalised.” Indeed, it does.
But parapsychology has decades of history in operationalizing
these things. The behavioural sciences in general, not to mention the biological sciences
and the physical sciences, are all going through major crises. Maybe
these crises are opportunities to begin to incorporate the empirical data of parapsychology
into our new paradigms. I don’t expect any of this to happen
rapidly, maybe not for another 50 or 100 years. But I’m issuing the call now
because this is what needs to take place.
Now, for those of you listening, let me ask you the question:
Are there phantasms, or tulpas, or egregores operating in your life?
Is it possible that some of your own thoughts have taken on a life of their own? Manifesting, not only
in the tendencies of your own consciousness, but perhaps even independently in the world around you?
Think about that. Thank you for being with me.
